title: Outrage after world famous Army ‘White Helmets’ motorcycle stunt team disbanded after being dubbed too old-fashioned by chiefs
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments ARMY top brass were blasted for disbanding the world famous “white helmets” motorcycle stunt team after chiefs decided it was too old-fashioned. 
Daredevils from of the Royal Signals Motorcycle Display Team have thrilled audiences at fetes and country shows with their stunts for the past 90 years. Alamy 5 The stunt team has been thrilling audiences for 90 years 
Displays include forming a motorcycle human pyramid, cycling backwards while juggling, bursting through a ring of fire and riding their 750cc bikes round a field with a colleague up a ladder. 
The much-loved team famously appeared on the Texaco advert in the 1980s and we’re regulars at the Royal Military Tournament. 
They currently have 22 performers who are all seconded from the Royal Signals and based in Blandford Camp in Dorset. Times Newspapers Ltd 5 White Helmets take part in the British Military Tournament 
But the Ministry of Defence has revealed they are taking no more bookings for the internationally-acclaimed team after this summer’s events. 
They are due to be replaced with a stunt display team to reflect the modern work carried out by the Royal Signals, it is claimed. Alamy 5 Stunt bikers are part of the Royal signals heritage 
One ex-serviceman said: “It’s a disgrace. It’s a classically British tradition and loved by families and children at shows held the length and breadth of the land. 
“Audiences will be devastated to hear its being dumped after 90 years because it looks old fashioned.”

“The white helmets are great to watch and doing the training with them was the greatest two weeks of my life not just my Army career. 
“I treasure those memory’s. Such a shame that these type of tours/ experiences have to end.” 
The White Helmet’s wages are paid for by the Army but costs of running the shows are paid for through charity, donations and ticket sales. 
On the official army website, the White Helmets are described as “Respected and consulted throughout the world”. Alamy 5 The motorcycle stunt team has thrilled generations 
They add: “A popular element of the Corps and makes a valuable contribution to keeping the Army in the public eye, showing off the Corps, and indeed representing Britain at events throughout the world.” 
They were formed in 1927 and made up of despatch riders. 
Furious servicemen have been blasting the decision on a Facebook group. 
Tony Gadson wrote: “The White Helmets Motorcycle Display team are legendary and were at one time probably the biggest recruiting tool the army had, especially in the days of the Royal Tournament.” Alamy 5 Performances help raise money for veterans and their families 
An Army spokesperson said: “The Royal Corps of Signals have come far since using motorbikes to carry messages across the battlefield, and are now highly trained ‘Leaders in a Digital Age’ with expertise in cyber operations.
